Let $f\in \mathbb{C}[x]$ be a monic polynomial with $m$ distinct roots, and let $c>0$ be a constant small enough such that $\{ z: \lvert f(z)\rvert\leq c\}$ has $m$ distinct connected components.

Must all these components be convex?



A question of Grunsky, which was reported by Erd\H{o}s, Herzog, and Piranian \cite{EHP58}.

The answer is no, as shown by Pommerenke \cite{Po61}, who showed that, if $k$ is sufficiently large, and $f(z)=z^k(z-a)$ where $a$ is sufficiently close to $(1+\frac{1}{k})k^{\frac{1}{k+1}}$, then $\{ z: \lvert f(z)\rvert\leq 1\}$ has two components, and the component which contains $0$ is not convex.

Goodman \cite{Go66} proved that one of the three components of\[\{ z: \lvert (z^2+1)(z-2)^2\rvert < 5^{3/2}/4\}\]is not convex (depicted {IMAGE=1047Goodman,here}, and constructed an example with simple roots, of degree $4$. The referee of the paper also gave the example of $\lvert z(z^5-1)\rvert<5.6^{-6/5}$ (depicted {IMAGE=1047Ref,here}).

Goodman raises the question of the maximum number of non-convex components that are possible as a function of the degree of $f$.




References


[EHP58] Erd\H{o}s, P. and Herzog, F. and Piranian, G., Metric properties of polynomials. J. Analyse Math. (1958), 125-148.

[Go66] Goodman, A. W., On the convexity of the level curves of a polynomial. Proc. Amer. Math. Soc. (1966), 358--361.

[Po61] Pommerenke, Ch., On metric properties of complex polynomials. Michigan Math. J. (1961), 97-115.
